item.description:
Victory Circle is a variant on the old Trap the Cap game.

The object of the game is to be the player with the most capped and/or captured pieces at the end of the game. You can only cap one piece at a time; it is best to drag the capped piece back to your Victory Circle --where it'll remain until the end of the game. When you cap a piece that is itself capping another, you get to keep either one capped, setting the other free (sending it back to its own Victory Circle). The green spaces are safe.

The game ends when all of a player's pieces are capped or captured. If keeping score, captured pieces are worth 3, capped pieces 1.

Sjoelen (Dutch) is also less commonly known as Dutch Shuffleboard (English) or Jakkolo (German). This dexterity game is particularly popular in the Netherlands, where it originated, hence Sjoelen is the official designation for the game. The World Championships are held every two years, with the most recent event in Czechoslovakia (15-16 May, 2015), and the next event planned for France (2017).

Playing involves each player having three rounds of sliding 30 wooden disks along a 2 metre long table in an attempt to get them through four arches numbered 1 to 4 at the other end. Getting disks into the low scoring compartments is just as important as the high ones because each set of 4 disks in the four compartments scores double (20 instead of 10 points).

Note that sjoelbak is the name of the board, not the game itself.

item.description:
Carrom is most easily described as "finger pool". On a 29" x 29" wooden board, players flick a large weighted disc (the striker) at smaller wooden discs (the carrom-men). The goal is to sink your 9 carrom-men (black or white), as well as the red Queen, in the four corner pockets. The first player or team to accomplish this collects points for the round (commonly called a "board"). A standard game of Carrom continues until one player has 25 points or 8 boards have been completed.

Carrom is typically played with powder, and some variations of the game use cues. The most widely played form of 'proper' Carrom is supported by a world wide set of rules known as The Laws of Carrom, and are available from the International Carrom Federation.

Carrom bears similarities to Pool and Crokinole, but is a fascinating game in its own right with varied strategies and techniques. No one knows exactly where the game originated. It could have come from Bangladesh, Burma, Egypt, or Ethiopia, but most believe it originated in India.

Also see American Carrom and the European games in a similar vein, Korona and H-ring spel.

item.description: This game is very similar to Monopoly. Players go around the board and buy cities, with infantry, subs, generals etc (rather than money). Once they have a set of any 2 cities in a county they can then build forts, which enables the fort owner to receive military units from other players who land on that city.

Designed to cash in on the popular remake of the classic sci-fi movie Planet of the Apes, the object of this game is to collect a set of items which will allow you to be the first to escape the planet through a time portal. The playing surface comprises 20 modular board units which are shuffled prior to play and therefore create a randomized labyrinth planet to be explored. 120 push-out cardboard tiles represent hidden bonuses and hazards and three special dice decide the combat and range of movement. Exploration elements work well and ensure no two games are the same. Dressing the board with the rather fiddly little tiles each time a new part of the maze is uncovered can become tedious. The cumulative effect of collected weapons can render a lucky player almost invincible very quickly, with the chimp warriors soon becoming superfluous and little more than an irritation.

A reasonable strategic exploration game for the younger player.

The object of the game is to move your six playing pieces from one side of the board to the opposite side. The game is played by either two or four players. The catch is that the pieces all look identical; they are identified by a colored ring on their underside only.

On your turn, you move a piece forward, sideways or diagonally, possibly jumping over a single piece (a series of jumps is possible if the right gaps are present, as in Checkers). When a piece reaches the far side, it is turned over to reveal its true owner. If yours, it stays there; if not, it reverts to its indistinguishable side and its true owner must move it on his next turn. During play, you can also challenge the ownership of a piece being moved. The incorrect player forfeits his turn.

The german Schmidt Spiele edition was published as a game of the Schmidt Spiele-Bar series in book case format.

You can win in either of two ways. Be the first to score five points (with the small token) before moving the large token onto the End Of The Line space or outlast the opponents so they all end up at the End Of The Line before you do, even if you score less.

The players simultaneously choose one of their 13 cards to play. Ties are discarded; of the remaining cards, the highest scores a point. Except for the discards, all players move their large tokens toward the End Of The Line by the amount played.

item.description:
The object of the game is to Push your Prince from its home position to one of the crowned squares on the opposite side of the board (the edge rows). This is achieved with the help of your eight Escort pieces.

On your turn, you move either your Prince (1, 2 or 3 steps) or an Escort (by its exact value: 3, 4, 5 or 6). Each step is horizontal, diagonal or vertical --but the board is odd. It is 33x33 with 64 3x3 tiles "punched out", some with a connected square remaining in the middle.

Jumps aren't allowed. A Push occurs when an Escort arrives short of another piece (Princes can't Push); what happens is that the Escort's remaining steps are transferred to the pushed piece --which may be an opposing piece or your own Prince. The pushed piece's move must be in a straight line, in the direction dictated by the collision. When the straight line isn't possible, deflection occurs as indicated in the rules. Compound pushes can occur, when a pushed piece in turn collides with another.

"Battle of the Frogs"

On a 7x9 chessboard, the central 3x3 area is marked off as the "Arena". Each player sits at a long edge and starts with his nine frogs (hollow plastic figurines, 7 cm along their largest dimension) filling that row. All frogs move like Chess knights. Light moves first. Capture is by landing on an opposing frog and is not mandatory. The object of the game is to line up three frogs horizontally, vertically or diagonally in the Arena in such a way that the opponent cannot break it up (by capture) on his next move. A draw occurs when both players are down to two frogs.

In advanced play, a frog that captures gets to move again, sort of like in Checkers. Other variations allowed include different starting dispositions (any can be used as long as they are player-symmetrical). Finally, the "alternate win" rule states that you can also win by reducing the opponent to two frogs.

item.description: A simple variant of Tic-Tac-Toe. The board measures 6x6 and is subdivided into nine 2x2 "boardlets" which can individually be turned. On your turn, you either place a marker *or* turn a boardlet ninety degrees. First player to line up four or more markers horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins.

The object of the game is to traverse the board from HOME to the OFFICE after dropping off one's commuters at their respective places of employment.

You start off with two commuters but may pick up extra ones before you're out of the Neighborhood Jaunt. Next is either the Interstate 500 or Suburban Gauntlet. After this is the Beltway Expressway, with a Car Pool Express Lane for the lucky bastards with three or more commuters on board. Finally, there is the Inner City Maze.

You normally roll two dice, but some road signs reduce that number to one die. Optional rules include Traffic Jams, Fender Benders, Public Parking, Double Parking and Baby Behind the Wheel.

item.description:
From the box:

Go Berzerk and play the exciting shoot-em-up game that's just as much fun as the arcade game of the same name! You and your opponent take turns controlling either the Humanoid Warrior or the indestructible Evil Otto and his robot army. Make the wrong move and your Humanoid will get zapped. You score points for every enemy robot your Humanoid zaps and a bonus if you get all six. You opponent gets a chance to be the Humanoid player and zap robots to score points later in the game. Score more points than your opponent and you'll win the game!

From the box:

In this game adapted from the TV series, follow Lucan, the boy raised by wolves, in his daring search for his parents. Travel with him on his danger-filled adventures, rescuing people and animals from perilous situations.

From the box:

Attention Mall Shoppers! The voice of the Mall has big news! Come inside and hear all about the giant sales and special bargains! Then join your friends on a wild shopping spree as you rush from store to store!

Press the console button and the Voice will tell you where to move and where to find the best sales. Hurry! Your friends may try to beat you to the bargains! See if you can be the first to buy six items. IF you need more money, make a quick stop at the bank!

To buy or bank - just insert your credit card into the slot and listen. You never know what the Voice of the Mall has "in store" for you!

item.description: JED = Just Employed Dimwit. Card game of climbing the corporate ladder. Cards are business card-sized of fictional companies. Players take on different roles, and income denotes which role you play. Your income can change based on how well you do each round, so you can be CEO one turn and eventually fall to JED if you're not careful.

A wargame of the feud between the Hatfields and McCoys. Pieces are individual clan members and some have special abilities. Stills produce moonshine, which can be saved as victory points in case the game ends in a wedding, or consumed to make your pieces riled up to fight more fiercely. Game ends when one side is wiped out, or in a wedding. If a young male clan member of one side fights a young female clan member of the other side who's been skinny-dipping and one whups the other without getting riled up, there's a wedding.

name.value: Harry Potter Les Couloirs de Poudlard

item.description:

Welcome to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, where staircases move, the doors aren't always doors, and paintings often hide secret passages. You will discover these halls to be full of surprises - which makes getting to class an adventure in itself!

Players travel the Halls of Hogwarts until they find and visit all classes on their Class Schedules in the order they appear on the schedule - from top to bottom. The first player to do so and return to the appropriate starting area wins the game!

item.description: Great introductory game similar to Candy Land. Spin the spinner and move you pawn to the first space with matching colors. If you land on a rhyme picture, you try to match it with the nursery rhyme on the board. If you do so, you move to that rhyme! The winner is the first person to make it to the Humpty Dumpty rhyme square.

name.value: Jack and the Beanstalk Memory Game

item.description:
From the box:

An ideal family game: challenging for all ages, yet a game that children frequently (usually!) can win against adults. Requires concentration, memory, and a bit of luck!

Note - it's a simple race game with a mechanism like Chicken Cha Cha Cha - you move forward if you can turn over a tile matching the space in front of your pawn. You continue to move until you cannot make a match.

From the box:

Here are the famous funny Sweet Pickles and here is the town they live in. Welcome!

Although the game is basically a simple collection game for the young child, it is made even more entertaining by the dialogue (suitable for early readers) from each of the animal characters. Reading is not required, only optional. The game is based on the characters created by Ruth Lerner Perle and Jacquelyn Reinach and illustrated by Richard Hefter.

The most basic of children's games. Spin the spinner and move your pawn the number of spaces. If you land on a draw a card space, you draw a card and move forward the number of spaces on the card (1, 2, or 3). Repeat until someone gets to the end of the board and wins.

name.value: The Goldilocks and the Three Bears Game
The Goldilocks and the Three Bears Game

item.description: Another simple children's game in the same vein as Candy Land. It's a race around the board. Spin the spinner and move your pawn to the next matching symbol on the trail. If you land on someone else, they have to move back to the previous space with the same symbol. Continue until someone wins.

item.description:
Sly isn't a single game but six different ones, sharing board and pieces. The board is 12x12, divided in 16 fields of 3x3, with field centres specially marked. The pieces come in four colours and each set consists of a cylinder, four triangles and six squares.

All games but Line up use the whole 12x12 grid as a playing area. Line Up only uses the center positions of the 16 3x3 fields to effectively yield a 4x4 grid of playing positions.

Solitaire Sly is for 1 player and is a variation on the old puzzle of removing pieces by selected jumps. The game starts in 6x6 grid of pieces, but pieces can jump outside the 6x6 area using the whole 12x12 board if desired.

Sniggle is a racing game for 2-4 players.

Line Up is an alignment two-player game played on a 4x4 grid with each player having two squares, two triangles and one cyclinder of his color.

Empire is an abstract two-four player wargame of sorts.

Blockade (two players) is a distant relative of Hnefatafl; each player tries to have his king escape whilst blocking the other's with his guards.

Gateway, finally, is a 2-4 player game where each tries to enter all his pieces by forming alignments with opposing pieces.

item.description:
In this heavily sponsored game, the players are advertising executives who try to land accounts with clients and earn money (through the accounts, speculation on the stocks of the companies whose accounts they hold, lotteries and random events) so as to buy their condo, room by room. First one to complete his condo wins.

Movement is controlled by a distance die (1-3) and a direction die (east, west, uptown, downtown, choice).

Very random, as the players have no influence on the values of the stocks of the accounts they hold, for example.

The object of the game is to score the most points by competing against other great white sharks for a limited supply of prey.

There are two levels of play. In the introductory game, the sharks circle around the outer board, attacking each other when they catch up or from the Circle or Attack spaces. After each fight, the winner takes 5 prey tokens from the loser. "Starve" and you lose a turn. Other spaces make you lose or gain prey tokens, and the Feeding Frenzy space causes a fight royale.

In the full game, the inner part of the board represents the prey population; when your movement allows, you can "dip" into and out of this part of the board to eat prey. Prey reproduces periodically, replenishing the inner board. Whoever fed the most after 10 to 20 rounds (depending on the number of players) wins. But if you're too greedy and you wipe out all prey, all sharks starve and everyone loses!

A distant relative of Clue, where each player tries to deduce the Suspect, Motive, Crime Location and Weapon cards that were put in the Cemetary at the game's outset. Suspicion cards change hands, some are revealed to all, and so on. You win by correctly deducing the four hidden cards. Deduce incorrectly and you've lost, however.

Each player draws cards from the Rolling Stock Deck and uses them to construct a passenger or freight train. Players then draw cards from the Operations Deck. Operations cards will be passenger cards, freight cards, special cards, or destination cards. Passenger cards may only be loaded on cars for passengers. Freight cards may only be loaded on freight cars. The destination cards govern the movement of the trains from place to place. Special cards are either disasters or opportunities.

(Note that this game is unrelated to Metro, which was coincidentally originally released with the title Iron Horse.)

The players are competing archaeologists on digs throughout Egypt. Each wants to publish more valuable discoveries than his competitors. Status points replace money. Discovery cards need to be collected (in sets) to form complete discoveries. From the rulebook's Introduction: "To play 'Expedition' is to find yourself transported at once to the banks of the Nile to a site in some remote desert area, whose sands hold the secrets of the ages."

From the rules:

While doing research, Dr. Banner became the victim of radiation gone wild. Now, in times of stress, he becomes transformed into the rampaging Incredible Hulk. He must build a lab to "cure" his terrible problem. Each player tries to build one for him. But watch out - the players must sometimes rev up and unlease The Hulk who could, in his rage, "smash up" the Labs that are being built! Players must rebuild and survive the Hulk's attacks to win. POW!

From the box:

Doctor! Doctor! Come Quick! It's poor Mr Illbert! He's sick in bed again. Does he have Burning Ears, or is it an outbreak of the dangerous Stiff Upper Lip? Maybe it's Love Sickness... Or is he Just Fakin'? If your diagnosis is correct, it'll speed you up the ladder from Medical Student to Chief Doctor! (and Mr. Illbert will be eternally grateful to you too).

item.description:
From the box:

Yogi and Boo Boo were at home in their cave. It was a nice day and the door was open. The aroma of fresh baked cakes and doughnuts drifted thru the open door. Yogi knew it came from Ranger Smith's Headquarters and he was determined to get a taste of the goodies. Boo Boo told Yogi he could get in real trouble if he tried to get them. Yogi said he would go alone but Boo Boo knew he would help his friend if he could. In this game, each player moves both Yogi and Boo Boo thru many adventures to be the first to get to the Ranger Station and all the sweets there.

Null Bock is the game of deer mating rituals. Cards include Bucks and Does which are played to a central "arena" or to peripheral areas by each player. Those in the center must constantly better the previous buck or doe, while there are separate rules for the periphery. Points are scored by collecting doe cards. The "null bock" (zero buck) is too cool to fight and has special abilities to overcome the strongest buck.

Board game rendition of the famous game show most frequently (and notably) hosted by Dick Clark. The object of the game is to describe items of a given subject to one's teammate as quickly as possible. Each team has thirty seconds for each list. The team with the most points after three rounds advances to the "Winners Circle" round.

In the "Winners Circle" one teammate must make a list of items which fit each of six different categories. If the teammate can guess all six subjects in under sixty seconds the team wins the big money. The team with the most money after three games is the winner.

The eight Milton Bradley games never used the actual Winner's Circle format, opting to use descriptions of items like the front game. The first three games were $10,000, with the Third Edition later repackaged as $20,000 with slightly different artwork to accommodate the change. The eighth game used $50,000, per the brief 1981 series.

item.description:
From the box:

Thunder is a unique card game based on the seasons of the year. The object of the game is to win tricks with cards played from your hand and be the first to reach a game winning score.

name.value: CrossWord: The New York Times Sunday Puzzle Game

item.description:
From the box:

Analyze the Sunday crossword clues, try to decide which ones their opponents don't know, then challenge them to fill in those answers. Go on the offensive with clue selections for your opponent to solve, then be part of the action as the grid fills up, points accumulate, and defensive play takes over. It's non-stop excitement until the last few open squares, when anyone can come from behind to win CrossWord!

From the rules:

The object of the game is to be the first player to collect and fill up his or her Farm Card with 19 Farm Items to win the game. The lucky farmer gets to wear the ORGANIC FARMER OF THE YEAR button - at least until the next game! During the game, farmers will discover various strategies they can employ - fair and square.

(Note - this is a Monopoly-styled game with plenty of education features and a booklet about organic farming).

From the box

Create your own ideal home with breathtaking house plans designed by one of the country's leading architectural firms, fabulous top-of-the-line building products and magnificent furniture from America's leading manufacturers of building products and home furnishings. Develop your strategy to move into your ideal home before your opponents do - using the very best products on the market today. All photos feature real building products, furniture and accessories that are actually available for sale in galleries and home centers!

From the box:

Fat Chance is a rollicking game for children that nutrition-conscious parents will love. Players move Fat Man pawns around the colorful game board trying to collect as FEW junk food pounds as possible. But the temptations are many and it's hard to resist "pie a la mound", "mozzarella mess", "sunday driver" and the "tube steak special" (sic). What a combination - Ugh! Just imagine what you'll feel like after stuffing yourself with all that junk! (yuk!) If you are lucky, though, you'll be able to sweat off some of those pounds in the steam bath. Then if you challenge another Fat Man to a Weigh-In, he'll be the one to flip down the scale not you. What a relief because the fewer pounds you gain the better your chances are of winning the game of Fat Chance.

item.description:
Unusual party game from the mid-trivia binge. Players are to collect five experience tokens and one skill chip from each of the seven intuitive areas. The game includes hundreds of props for the different intuitive skills, which are as follows:

Pattern Perception: name a word which is printed in a very blurred fashion.

Psycho-Osmosis: Determine the meaning of a selected Hieroglyph.

Analysis: Select the two points of a large maze which are connected.

Imagination: Draw an abstract image card and name four things it could be (may require a vote from fellow players).

Connection: Draw two abstract image cards and state how they could be connected.

Recall: Look at an image and recall five or more of the eight items depicted.

Recognition: Look at an image card, then turn it over and point out the three images which weren't on the face.

The trick here is that all these actions have a 12-second time limit. No analysis paralysis. Players pretty much have to shoot from the hip or, that is to say, use their intuition.

A second edition was published and the meta-game of this edition was to intuitively figure out the exact date and time of that release. First 100 correct guessers were to receive a limited 2nd edition.

This is a party game loosely based on the popular weekly magazine of the same name. Players roll dice to determine the category and method to use for the round. In attempting to get one's teammates to guess the celebrity within the particular category, they must use one of four methods: impersonations, charades, word associations, or drawing - before the time runs out. You can also wager some of your points to increase the payoff.

From the box:

Extra Sensory Perception is the ability to send or receive thoughts, using only your mind to do so. Do you have this supernatural power? Kreskin, the world’s foremost authority on ESP, thinks you do. You need only to develop it. This fascinating ESP game shows how!

Imagine the fun! Alone, or with a friend, or with a whole party of people, players can reveal their innermost thoughts on love, politics, or any other subject. Kreskin’s ESP game will give you the opportunity to reveal your ESP powers and explore the outer frontiers of the human mind in two scientifically proven ways.

Similar to an Ouija board, this game includes several tricks and a magic pendulum which can be used to determine answers to yes/no questions and even spell out words.

From correspondence with Kreskin, December 2010:

Regarding your inquiry about the Kreskin ESP game, yours truly designed the game. As far as the artwork for the box, the Milton Bradley people had their staff do that. At one point, the amount of sales was over a million and it approached two million.
 Thank you for your interest about the game. It became a very popular showcase, as I played it with many people on television, including Johnny Carson, Mike Douglas, and Merv Griffin, as the pendulum proved to be a fascinating phenomena.
 With all my best thoughts,
Kreskin

item.description:
From the box

Deduction - the game that makes thinking fun! Deduction is the great new game for the entire family... a challenge of wits and deductive reasoning. Both players secretly set up one of thousands of possible color patterns. The excitement builds as you race to duplicate your opponents pattern... move by move... before he duplicates yours.

Swedish Roulette is an exciting version of the Big Casino game that will provide all the drama and suspense of the Monte Carlo original. 8 small balls, one of which is red, are placed in the center of the bowl. A player then spins the top. As the top spins, the body of it will hurl the balls knocking them about in the bowl. Action continues until the spinning top settles down. Scores are totaled by adding the numbers above the balls that have remained in a recessed spot along the outer edge of the bowl. The red ball scores double.

From the box:

A roll of the dice decides where you place your marble on the board. Don't like your roll? You get a second chance! 3 in a row scores one point. Four in a row scores two points. Get the point? Build your rows or block your opponents. There's fun and strategy on every roll, and doubles are always WILD!

The board is a grid, with the numbers 3-11 along each edge. Two blue dice determine which blue column, two red dice determine which red row, and you place your marble where they meet. Doubles are wild, so you can choose where to place your marble. If your opponent has a marble at that spot and it's not part of a three-in-a-row, you have a roll off, 3 dice and three chances, to see who can get the highest roll and claim that spot. Once a marble is part of a three-in-a-row it is locked in. Points are counted for a three-in-a-row in every direction; horizontally, vertically, and diagonally. The game ends when someone runs out of marbles, and everyone has a final turn.

1999 Mensa Select
